title: 12 best clothes airers and drying racks that make drying washing easier
text:
Got a load to dry and it's tipping down outside? Smothering hot radiators with damp clothes isn’t advisable; it's been shown that spores can be produced which affect the lungs; not to mention the health dangers from condensation and mould damage to walls.

Considering costs for even the most energy-efficient tumble dryers can stack up, make a greener choice by drying your laundry indoors, naturally.

Even in the smallest space there are solutions to get clothes air-dried.

The racks we’ve chosen fit a range of areas in the home, from a large utility room to the smallest corner of a student bedsit.

Always lie woollen garments flat, not folded, and ensure all items are laid with as few moisture-trapping creases as possible.

If you’re a last-minute launderer who often needs garments in a hurry, try a heated airer that gently heats widely-spaced bars.

We gave a mixed load of laundry the usual cycle each evening and put our selection of clothes airers to the test with great results.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps us to fund journalism across The Independent.

Leifheit lino pop up 140 airer: £65, Argos

New for 2019, this airer is perfect if you have limited space as it could easily fit a couple of washing loads onto its compact lines. Easy to open and close – just push down on the sturdy button or pull up on the collar – and it transforms into a whirligig style airer that sits firmly on four legs. When stored in its drawstring bag it’s tall, but easy to fit in a tiny corner of a broom cupboard. This airer is great for outdoors too as it’s a doddle to move around. When the weather allows, whisk it out onto a balcony or chase the sun around the garden.

Buy now

Dry:Soon deluxe 3-tier heated airer and accessories: £162.96, Lakeland

Join the army of fans of Lakeland’s laundry life-saver – you’ll never tumble dry again. The heated bars are just warm enough to dry undies and lighter items in a few hours and jeans overnight, especially if you opt for this bundle, which has the airer cover to trap the heat inside. Other features include castors for easy movement when fully-loaded, mesh shelves for drying knitwear and delicates and a peg system for undies. The handy clips and plug holder make storage neat and tidy, while the eight-hour timer is a nice addition. It costs just 6p an hour to run.

Buy now

Brabantia linn large clothes rack: £144, Brabantia

More a functional piece of furniture than a wobbly drier, this clothes rack looks the absolute business, whether in a kitchen, hallway or bedroom. We used ours in a utility space, with spun items going on hangers straight from the machine, damp undies hung on the upper higher rack and folded clothes on the bottom shelf, ready to be put away. It was great to have the height to throw duvet overs over the top to air dry. Versatile and stylish, we loved it. Also comes in black and in a smaller size.

Buy now

Garden Trading birch extending clothes dryer: £125, Amazon

This dryer comes in a tasteful dark grey or cream-painted finish, and is great for a utility room. The concertina joints extend to give you 10 zinc rails to hang laundry on, then folds back against the wall when not in use. The shelf on top of the unit is useful for storing laundry powder or folded items and the pegs beneath come in handy if you want to dry a shirt on its hanger.

Buy now

Addis over the door airer: £12.99, Addis

We won’t pretend this ingenious airer is capacious enough to take on a family load, but our student tester told us it was a brilliant addition to her tiny hall’s bedroom, as without much floor space she could dry undies and towels on the back of the door instead. The hooks underneath were perfect for hanging her jacket and dressing gown and the whole thing could fold flat if not needed. A bargain, too.

Buy now

Addis easi 3-tier airer: £32.50, Amazon

A quality rack with sturdy struts and joints, this comes with a three-year guarantee. In a quality grey and turquoise finish, there’s plenty of room for a larger load of wet wash. We like that it's really easy to put up and use. Wide-set bars make for easy hanging and to assemble the airer, just pull the concertina action via a soft-grip handle on its top.

Buy now

Minky over bath airer: £22.99, Minky

If you’re in a small flat and don’t want to stare at wet washing in your living area, try this Minky number, which you can hide away in the most underused space of all – the bath. The chunky feet are just the right shape to fix this to the bath edges and it will give 9.5 valuable metres of drying space – enough for a 6kg machine load. Wet washing was out of sight and out of mind in the smallest room – brilliant!

Buy now

Ikea frost clothers drier: £10, Ikea

Here’s a basic, lightweight plastic-coated hanger with a bargain price tag that’s sturdy enough to take daily use. Go mad and buy two! They also fold flat for easy storage. The adjustable height means they can easily handle longer items of laundry.

Buy now

Dry:Soon drying pod airer: £59.99, Lakeland

This model works like a small heater that blows air upwards into a fabric “pod” that has a hanger for drying up to 12 items inside. You can set the timer for up to three hours – we certainly needed that for several pairs of heavy jeans at once. More successfully, our tester filled the pod with 12 shirts for the working week ahead and found they were cupboard dry in around an hour and a quarter. We’d use this for delicates every day of the week, as they came out with very few creases too.

Buy now

Vileda premium 2 in 1 indoor table drier: £27.99, Amazon

If you want to dry indoors, use this well-constructed airer on wheels. If you hate ironing, you’ll appreciate the slightly wider drying bars which mean fewer creases on drying garments. We also like the way the “wings” on each side of the drier can be removed and hooked over a door or balcony for outdoor drying. Top marks for versatility. This one has an 18m capacity.

Buy now

Beldray large stainless steel clothes airer: £19.99, Amazon

This is such a versatile airer, with lots of different ways to hang clothes and air shoes – great for those of us who chuck smelly trainers in the machine. A fold-flat model, it also has an extendable top rail that helps when drying longer dresses and sheets. Its 13-metre drying space means lots of room to hang out a large-capacity machine load of washing.

Buy now

Laundry Tree clothes airer: £39.96, Thane Living

An ingenious idea if a traditional clothes horse would get in the way. Take advantage of vertical hanging space, with this system of expandable poles and hooks that will hold up to 55 garments at a time. It's easy to slot together and the tension spring inside means it fits snugly to ceiling heights of 2.6 metres. Our tester loved it for ironing sessions too, using hangers to store newly-pressed shirts and keeping items in place as she used a hand-held steamer.

Buy now

The verdict: Clothes airers and drying racks

The Dry:Soon bundle may seem like a huge investment, but when it’s Sunday night and you have sopping wet school uniform or work shirts to dry, you’ll know it’s worth the money.

Get rid of your environmentally-unfriendly tumble drier and make space in the kitchen or utility for it. The Addis Easi Airer is also a good, robust drier that’s easy to store if your budget is more modest.

description: Dry your washing with ease inside with one of these clothes airers and drying racks from Ikea, Minky, Vileda, Addis and Beldray
